sourcesContent:
import React from 'react'; import '../App.css'; import Disclaimer from '../../components/Disclaimer'; const CairnMaintenance = () =>{ return (

Positive Reinforcement Training

Positive Reinforcement Training or PRT I feel is the best and only way to train any breed, big or small. The overall concept behind it is only rewarding positive behavior and discouraging any negative or bad behavior. While training using the PRT method no physical abuse like slapping or hitting should ever be done or needed. PRT is more effective than any other training method I have found and will never require slapping, hitting, or shocking.

Again this goes for cairns all the way up to mastiffs, you never need to hit a dog to teach it. When training, avoid using their main source of food as a reward or this can lead to food bowl aggression. Also, when or if your puppy does something bad like pee on the floor or chew something they shouldn't, DO NOT slap or hit them. A good way to help avoid unwanted chewing is to help make sure they have toys of their own that aren't similar to other items in the house.

Vaccines & Medications

Do what your veterinarian recommends as certain vaccines are more crucial to have in different parts of the country than others. Certain parts of the country have different types of potential dangers. For example, some parts of the country have wood ticks while others do not, some have more species of parasitic worms due to climate and winter temperature allowing, some parasites to live in thrive in some areas.

Some gruesome facts about parasites like the heartworm are commonly transmitted from being on a mosquito's mouth before the mosquito bites your puppy. I do not regularly treat mine for fleas or ticks and never had problems. When I will be traveling with them, they will be using shared pet relief areas, so I know I have to administer a prevention Medication for fleas and ticks as well as hookworm, ringworm, and heartworm. I have used Trifexis for a once a month pill for prevention for all of the above.
Alone Time
Just like most other dogs, Cairns do not like to be left alone. If they are left alone for extended periods of time you can experience destructive behavior from your cairn like barking, not listening, possible attitude, etc. Mine will often give me "the look" like where have you been and what took you so long.

I often refer to this as there little aggressions, they are just like people too, they need and crave your time and attention. I will always leave the light on as well as the tv when I am gone for longer periods. Most of the time our cairns come with us into stores, on planes, pretty much everywhere, as they are my children's service animals and have helped them in more ways than I ever imagined!


); } export default CairnMaintenance;
